 STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT REPUBLIC OF KAZAKSTAN PILOT REAL ESTATE REGISTRATION PROJECT I. PROJECT BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE A. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The Government of Kazakstan has requested World Bank assistance to finance a pilot project that will design and test models for the implementation of the real estate registration system called for under the Presidential Decree with the force of law, "On State Registration of Rights and Transactions in Real Estate" of December 25, 1995 (henceforth, the Registration Law). The proposed project will be implemented in 34 rayons in Almaty and Akmola oblasts and in Almaty city. The primary counterpart for the project will be the Ministry of Justice. In addition, the State Land Committee and the Ministry of Construction will play important roles in implementation. The end objective of the pilot project will be to provide a reliable foundation for the implementation of a real estate registration system on a national basis. Contingent upon successful implementation of the pilot project, the World Bank would be prepared to continue to assist the Government in the implementation of a larger project with the objective of expansion of the real estate registration system nationwide. B. THE IMPORTANCE OF REAL ESTATE REGISTRATION SYSTEMS 1.2 Registration systems, which authoritatively record the ownership of rights in land and real estate, are an essential component of the economic infrastructure of market economies. Registration systems serve as the single source of official information about rights in land and real estate, representing formal recognition and confirmation of these rights by government authorities. Registration systems also serve as the official means by which transactions in land and real estate are recorded and legally validated. By bringing clarity, certainty, and authority to rights and transactions in land and real estate, registration systems greatly enhance security of tenure. This encourages efficient use of resources and stimulates long-term investment. A large number of rights in land and real estate have been established in Kazakstan. As the process of economic reform moves forward, the number of rights, and of transactions involving those rights, will increase tremendously. C. PROPERTY RIGHTS IN LAND AND REAL ESTATE IN KAZAKSTAN 1.3 Kazakstan has in place a reliable legal basis defining property rights in land and real estate and facilitating the exercise of those rights. The new Constitution and Part One of the Civil Code, both introduced in 1995, provide the basic framework for real property rights in land and real estate. A number of important Presidential Decrees were issued in December 1995 which further clarified the question of the extent and nature of property rights in land and real estate. On December 23, 1995 a Presidential Decree with force of law "On the Mortgage of Real Estate" was issued elaborating upon the general rules on pledges, as laid out in the Civil Code. It allows for the mortgage of all forms of real estate with some limitations in cases where property is held in common ownership, and includes the provision that special aspects of mortgage of land may be stipulated in separate legislation.
 - 2 - 1.4 Another Presidential Decree with the force of law "On Land" was issued on December 22, 1995 (commonly referred to as the Land Code). It replaced a Land Code dating to the Soviet period and consolidated treatment of land policy issues that bad been handled by a patchwork of statutes issued since independence. The new Land Code provides for private as well as state ownership of land. A private land owner is entitled, inter alia, to sell, lease, mortgage, or grant his property. The Code also establishes use rights in state owned land that largely replicate the rights held by owners. Use rights can be permanent, long-term (3-99 years) and short-term (less than 3 years). Individual holders of both permanent and long-term use rights are entitled to sell, lease, mortgage, or grant their rights. These provisions are sufficient for the development of markets in land in non-agricultural sectors of the economy. 1.5 The Land Code is more restrictive of rights in agricultural land, however. Agricultural land that is held in the personal household plots, and the garden and dacha plots can be privately owned. All other agricultural land, including the land of private farmers, can be held in permanent use rights, but not private ownership. However, land held collectively in use rights (i.e., the land of the large farming collectives) cannot be alienated or mortgaged. 1.6 The Land Code allows for the allocation of land to those exiting the large farming collectives as well as other people interested in starting private farms. For individuals exiting the farming collectives, land is to be allocated from the collective in accordance with locally determined land share norms. For individuals coming from outside of the large collectives, or for members of state agricultural enterprises that are not subject to parcelization (e.g., research and breeding farms), land is provided from a Land Reserve Fund, administered by local government. 1.7 At present there are an estimated 4.5 million land owners and users whose rights are subject to registration. Furthermore, there are an estimated 2.2 million members of the large farming collectives who are entitled to land share certificates. The majority of apartments and houses in Kazakstan have been privatized. an Almaty, 99 percent of the apartments have been privatized.) These ownership rights and subsequent transactions are also subject to registration. The level of transactions in real estate is increasing in Almaty, with several hundred occurring each day. Roughly 2,000 medium sized enterprises have been privatized. Approximately 11,000 small scale establishments have been sold by the Government since the beginning of the mass privatization program early in 1994, representing two-thirds of the total number of such objects. D. EXISTING INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK 1.8 During the Soviet period, there was a major distinction made between treatment of land, on the one hand, and treatment of improvements to land (buildings, structures, etc.), on the other. This resulted in a complex set of agencies and institutions that are involved in collecting and maintaining information on land and real estate. Furthermore, the relatively low importance accorded to property rights meant that the bulk of this information was technical, rather than legal, in orientation. Since the early 1990's, recording of private rights in land and real estate has been underway. The system that evolved in the last few years, however, lacks coherence and unity, and suffers from a lack of professional legal oversight. 1.9 The Ministty of Justice. In many countries, the ministries of justice administer the real estate registry. This is the approach adopted by Kazakstan in the recently issued Registration Law. However, the Ministry of Justice has little experience in this area. It has undertaken the registration of
 legal entities, but has neither the experience nor the institutional capacity at present to undertake real estate registration. The Ministry of Justice is represented at the oblast and rayon levels, and this system will form the basis of new registration offices called for in the Registration Law. Existing staffing of the Ministry of Justice at the regional and local levels is not adequate for registration and additional hiring will be required. 1.10 The State Land Commitee (Goskomzem). The State Land Committee was established in 1992, drawing largely from the Land Department of the Ministry of Agriculture. Its Chairman is a Cabinet Minister. Goskomzem's functions include: (i) the administration and management of land resources; (ii) the monitoring and control of land use; (iii) the protection of land; and (iv) the creation of a nation-wide land cadastre. Goskomzem has been responsible for the registration of land use rights and the issue of land use certificates (Land Acts). Since 1992, roughly 1.6 million Land Acts have been issued and an additional 0.7 million are in preparation. This compares with a total of approximately 4.5 million land owners and users whose rights are subject to registration. The Land Acts contain important legal information concerning a land parcel, including a description of its location, a survey depiction of its boundaries, and identification of the user. However, for the purposes of the legal cadastre, there is insufficient information on encumbrances and servitudes. 1.11 Goskomzem records the issue of Land Acts chronologically at the local level. This system is inadequate from the point of view of information management. Continuation of this system over time would result in difficulty in locating relevant legal information for a given parcel. The adoption of the new Registration Law replaces the existing legal basis for land registration. 1.12 Goskomzem employs about 600 staff with headquarters in Almaty and branch offices in each Oblast (Oblkomzem), City (Gorkomzem) and Rayon (Raykomzem). The staff are predominantly surveyors and engineers. Branches are subject to dual subordination, reporting to their local government administration as well as to headquarters in Almaty. 1.13 A subsidiary of Goskomzem, GosNPCzem (The State Scientific-Production Center for Land), provides technical services for recording land parcels and for preparing State Acts. The production of State Acts is partially computerized in some locations. GosNPCzem used to form part of the Ministry of Agriculture. Its main functions were: (i) to design and manage large-scale agricultural development and improvement schemes; and (ii) to maintain the agricultural cadastre by means of which Soviet agriculture was planned and managed. GosNPCzem employs approximately 2300 staff including surveyors, engineers, agronomists, soil scientists and economists and maintains offices in each Oblast. 1.14 Another subsidiary of Goskomzem is the State Institute for Agricultural Aerophotogeodetic Surveys (GISKhAGI). GISKhAGI was established in 1936 as part of the Ministry of Agriculture to produce mapping for the agricultural cadastre. In 1992, it was transferred to Goskomzem and has since undertaken some mapping of non-agricultural areas. The agricultural cadastre parcel maps have been produced in the form of line maps and photoplans at scales from 1:10,000 to 1:50,000. GISKhAGI also produces large scale mapping at 1:5,000 and larger in urban and peri-urban areas. 1.15 As part of a recent Government reorganization, the Main Administration for Geography and Cartography (Kazgeodesia) has been merged into Goskomzem. Goskmomzem thereby became the primary civilian mapping agency in the country. As a result of this merger, its mandate was expanded to include: (i) providing geodetic and topographic survey and mapping services; (ii) international boundary demarcation; and (iii) the licensing of other agencies to undertake surveys and mapping works.
 - 4 - Kazgeodesia was traditionally responsible for the production of topographic base-mapping at scales ranging from 1:500 to 1:100,000 for the whole territory of Kazakstan, together with small scale mapping and other thematic maps. 1.16 The Ministry of Construction. The Ministry of Construction is the focal point within the Government for information on buildings. It has offices in each oblast. Until recently, the Ministry of Construction administered the offices of the Bureau of Technical Inventory (see below). In recent years this administrative subordination has been broken. The Ministry of Construction continues to have oversight responsibility for the Rayon and City Architect's Offices, which exist in the largest cities and in each oblast in Kazakstan. 1.17 Rayon and City Architect's Offices. The City Architect's Offices produce large scale (1:500 to 1:2,000) maps for architectural and engineering construction purposes. Coverage is restricted to urban areas and is often based on mapping produced by Kazgeodesia. The Rayon or City Architect is responsible for planning the physical infrastructure, for coordinating development activity, for approving construction plans and for monitoring construction. Following construction, the Rayon or City Architect's Office surveys the site and adds the structure/facility to their maps. Since the map updating process is so closely linked to the approval process, the maps are theoretically current. 1.18 The Almaty City Architect's Office employs approximately 10 surveyors involved in updating the 1:2,000 scale maps and 4 devoted to the 1:500 scale series. In Almaty the City Architects Office has converted approximately 30 percent of the 1:2,000 scale maps to digital form utilizing AutoCAD. 1.19 The Bureaus of Technical Inventory (BTIs). BTI offices exist in most cities and large towns. The BTIs have for many years acted as the organization responsible for recording the occupation and tenure rights of buildings, in particular apartments and houses. As a result, BTIs have amassed detailed records of the location, construction, facilities, services and equipment of urban buildings. Until recently, the BTIs were under the joint jurisdiction of the Ministry of Construction and the local government administration. Since 1993, the BTIs have undergone administrative changes. Most are no longer subordinate to the Ministry of Construction and in many large cities have been privatized. Increasingly their orientation is focused on real estate appraisal. Most have changed their titles to include the term "Real Estate Appraisal Board" or "Real Estate Appraisal and Registration Board". 1.20 BTI's records form the basis for the privatization of dwellings; a prospective owner is able to obtain from BTI evidence of his/her prior occupation, as a preliminary step to an application for privatization. The culmination of the privatization process is the issue of a Privatization Act. The Privatization Act includes technical information (the "Technical Passport") describing the property and its location, as well as information on the owner/user. In distinction from the State Acts for land, the Privatization Acts for dwellings in some parts of the country include reliable information on encumbrances. BTIs have also acted as the registration authority for transactions in buildings. A transaction is effected by transferring a Privatization Act from vendor to purchaser, and registering the transfer at the local BTI. BTIs registration records are keyed to its own numbering system for buildings, which is inconsistent with a parcel based identification system.
 1.21 The State Propery Committee (Goskomimuschestvo). The State Property Committee is responsible for the privatization of state-owned enterprises. It prepares and issues "Privatization Acts" for such transactions. The Ministry of Justice has responsibility for registering the privatized enterprises. 1.22 Public Notaries. The Public Notaries are employed by the State and report to the Ministry of Justice. There is a minimum of one Notary office per rayon. Notaries act as intermediaries between buyer and seller for real estate and land. Notaries prepare standard contracts for the sale and transfer of property. As a condition of the preparation of such documents the Notary verifies that all supplementary documents are properly constituted, that the necessary taxes and fees have been paid to the appropriate authorities, and that the current obligations associated with the rights to be transferred have been met. The contract of sale is executed by the parties and certified by the Notary. 1.23 Local Government Administration. Local administrations have a pivotal role in the allocation of land and other real estate rights, and in the control of land use within their boundaries. They combine the functions of: (i) disposing of and qualifying the rights in terms of the uses to be permitted; (ii) controlling construction through the architecture and construction committees; (iii) registering the ownership, occupation and value of buildings through BTI; and (iv) registering the ownership of land use rights through the local Land Committee office. E. PRINCIPLES OF REAL ESTATE REGISTRATION 1.24 The experience of countries which have established successful real estate registers suggests that certain principles should be incorporated: 1.25 Principle 1: Unification. A real estate register must be unified in the sense that it must record the rights to all land, whether urban or rural, agricultural or industrial, as well as rights to all real estate, including rights in land parcels which are delineated by horizontal as opposed to vertical boundaries, as in the case of apartment buildings. 1.26 Principle 2: Impartial and Independent. A real estate register is maintained by the State for the benefit of those who own rights in land or who use the register to identify owners as a means of ensuring certainty in transactions. As a guardian of public rights, the registry must be separated from the executive functions of government. Managers of the register make no decisions about who is granted land rights or who transacts them nor how land use is controlled. This role distinguishes the register from other forms of land record which may be designed to enable the State to fulfil its responsibilities such as master planning or tax collection. 1.27 Principle 3: Governed by Law. The registry should be established by a law which defines the powers and responsibilities of its managers. The agency has no power to refuse registration of a lawfully acquired right to land. 1.28 Principle 4: State Indemnity. The legal effect from the moment of registration should be to grant the State's guarantee of the validity of the title registered, against any claim to the contrary. Thus the State indemnifies the registered owner against such claims. 1.29 Principle 5: Parcel-Based. The unit of registration should be the land parcel as identified by a unique index number. The land parcel, delineated by its vertical boundaries, is unique and cannot
 - 6 - be changed (although it may be sub-divided). In the case of buildings in multiple ownership a parcel may be delineated by horizontal boundaries i.e., floors in the building. The parcel-based unit of registration is adopted as the key because it is finite and unchanging, whereas names of owners of rights change over time. 1.30 Principle 6: Coordination with Physical Cadastres. Coordination between the real estate register (the legal cadastre) and the cadastre for land and buildings must be well defined for the registration system to function efficiently. This coordination should include delineation of responsibilities for information collection and maintenance so as to reduce overlap and duplication, and reliable channels for the flow of information between the legal and physical cadastres. 1.31 Principle 7: Adjudication and Demarcation. The register should be compiled by a process known as 'Adjudication'. By means of this process all rights in land, whether statutory or customary, are finally and authoritatively determined by due process of law, prior to registration. Adjudication does not alter the rights but simply identifies and demarcates the location, nature, extent and ownership of rights in each parcel. Adjudication must include a procedure for appeals. 1.32 Principle 8: Register Priority. For the purposes of proving good title, it is the entry in the register which is the official proof not the certificate issued to the holder of the rights. This principle ties in with Principle 4 because the State is unable to prevent fraudulent use, alteration or counterfeiting of certificates. 1.33 Principle 9: Adverse Claims. The system should incorporate provisions for the filing of adverse claims and the rapid resolution for such claims. 1.34 Principle 10: Open to the Public. The register should be open and accessible to the public. This enables the owners of rights to be clearly identified for example, by those wishing to deal in rights. F. THE NEW REGISTRATION SYSTEM 1.35 The Registration Law addresses nearly all of the principles laid out above. It establishes a system for the unified registration of rights in land and real estate. It creates a Registration Body as part of the Ministry of Justice and defines the concept of the Legal Cadastre, which represents the information base for the registration system. The Law further clarifies the rights which are subject to registration and the general procedures to be followed in registering those rights. The Law calls for a parcel based system of managing information. It establishes the principle of priority and addresses the question of adverse claims. Further, it provides for public access to information in the registry and delineates the bases for suspending or refusing registration. 1.36 The Registration Law leaves open a number of important questions about the practical functioning of the registration system. Foremost among these is the linkage with the land and buildings cadastres and the way in which introduction of the new system is coordinated with the existing arrangements for registration of rights in real property (the Land Acts for land issued by Goskomzem and the Privatization Acts issued by the BTIs). The Registration Law leaves the format of the registration book and the registration forms for individual properties (the registration sheets) undefined. For the system to operate effectively, standard forms for various types of transactions (sale, lease, mortgage,
 inheritance, etc.) need to be defined and utilized. Procedures for handling documents from the time they enter the registration offices until they are either returned to the client or filed in the legal cadastre need to be defined. The Registration Law also leaves undefined the system of fees for service and fees allocation, and procedures for assignment of cadastral numbers to land parcels. 1.37 Since issuing the Registration Law in December, the Government has undertaken work to address the missing elements of the system. An inter-agency Working Group for implementation of the Registration Law was established by then Deputy Prime Minister Shaikenov on March 4, 1996. The Working Group is composed of representatives of the Ministry of Justice, the State Land Committee, the Ministry of Construction, and the BTI offices for both the city and oblast of Almaty. Its mandate is to address the issues of coordination of functions and successful implementation of the system. The last Preparation Mission on this project met intensively with representatives of the Working Group to solidify common positions and understandings on inter-agency cooperation and coordination. On April 12, 1996 the Government issued a formal Agreement signed by the Ministry of Justice, the State Land Committee, and the Ministry of Construction "On Inter-Agency Cooperation" which includes a commitment on the part of all signatories to work toward the successful implementation of the Registration Law. In particular, it states that the Land Committee offices, the BTIs, and the City Architects' Offices will provide necessary information on land parcels and buildings for the efficient functioning of the legal cadastre (Annex A). During the Appraisal Mission, the arrangements for inter-agency cooperation were further elaborated with representatives of the Ministry of Justice, the State Land Committee, and the Ministry of Construction. It was agreed that these arrangements would be formally established in a Government Resolution on registration procedures. This Resolution was issued on February 20, 1997. 1.38 The Bank has provided the Government with sample registration sheets and books from other countries. From this and other sources, the Government is now approaching closure on the format for these items in Kazakstan. The Government has also come to closure on the system of assigning cadastral numbers to land parcels. Issuing official documents defining the format for the registration sheets and book, document handling procedures, and inter-agency cooperation arrangements will provide an adequate basis to initiate project implementation, with the pilot functioning to further elaborate operational aspects of the system.

RATIONALE FOR BANK INVOLVEMENT 2.1 The project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy as discussed by the Board of Directors during the presentation of the Technical Assistance Loan (3642-KZ) on August 3, 1993. The Bank's strategy to assist the Government of Kazakstan is founded on four key pillars to provide support for: (i) macroeconomic stabilization and price reform; (ii) transformation of the economy to a competitive, market-based system through privatization of state enterprises and the encouragement of competition from new market participants; (iii) strengthened capacity for social protection; and (iv) rehabilitation and improved management capacity for public infrastructure. The proposed project fits directly into this strategy. It will provide a system to reliably record emerging private rights in land and real estate, thereby facilitating transactions in those rights including sale, lease, mortgage, and grant. Security of tenure resulting from the system will in turn encourage investment in land, enterprises and other property. The proposed project will provide the basis for testing implementation of an important piece of the public infrastructure necessary for a market-based economy. Based on successful implementation of the pilot project, a fuller project would be prepared for implementation of the registration system on a nation-wide basis. 2.2 The Structural Adjustment Loan (SAL) for Kazakstan, inter alia, addressed the issue of land market development. The Letter of Economic Reform Policies contained provisions for the clarification of land policies through the preparation of a new draft Land Code, and fostering efficient and equitable real estate markets and alleviating potential conflicts over land rights through the detailed definition of procedures for registration of real estate. Development of land reform, and in particular, the development of the land cadastre and the system of registration are featured in the Government's Program of Actions for Deepening the Economic Reforms during 1996-98. Subsequent to the first tranche of the SAL, a Land Code and Registration Law have been issued. The Government now requires assistance in moving beyond this legislative foundation in elaborating and implementing a sound real estate registration system. 2.3 The Agricultural Sector Review (ASR) identified the lack of a land registration system as one of the binding constraints to the transformation of the sector to a market-based orientation. The ASR argued that the absence of an effective registration system for both land and buildings is constraining privatization and development. An Agriculture Privatization Support Project is now in preparation which will focus on the process of structural change in farm management with the goal of facilitating the emergence of more efficient farms. A critical aspect of the farm restructuring process will be the establishment of private rights in the land and property of the existing large collective farms. For the farm restructuring process to move forward effectively, a reliable system for registering these newly emerging rights will be essential. 2.4 The World Bank has recently approved US$180 million Financial Sector Adjustment Loan (FSAL). One part of the financial sector program that the FSAL addresses is strengthening the framework for secured lending. Important in this regard is a reliable system for determining rights in real property. The proposed project will provide the basis for the satisfaction of these requirements.
 - 9 - m. BANK EXPERIENCE AND LESSONS A. EXPERIENCE 3.1 The Bank's limited experience in financing land titling and registration is based mainly on components of large rural or agricultural development projects, or free-standing land projects. Since 1980, 17 PCRs or PPARs have been prepared for projects with land as a component and two PCRs for free-standing land projects. The two land projects are the Northeast Region Land Tenure Improvement Project for Brazil (Ln. No. 2593-BR) and the Land Titling Project for Thailand (Ln. No. 2440-TH). A recent OED report entitled The World Bank's Experience with Rural Land 7itling (No. 1992-35, March 1992) has also summarized Bank experience and lessons in land registration. 3.2 Experience has been mixed. In the majority of projects, performance has fallen short of targets. In some cases, cost overruns for land titling have been large. Data from most rural and agricultural development projects in particular, show considerable cost overruns. Costs per land parcel adjudicated in Brazil were nearly twice the estimates made during appraisal. On the other hand, cost per parcel adjudicated in Thailand was lower than estimated. Mapping targets were generally met with less of a tendency for cost overruns. However, delays in their implementation contributed to delays in titling. 3.3 The factors which have contributed to poor performance can be traced to inappropriate or ambitious design and over-optimistic assumptions about implementation. According to OED, the four main reasons for poor performance of land titling projects are: (i) lack of political support; (ii) conflicting bureaucratic priorities and/or infighting; (iii) lack of institutional capacity or unwillingness to commit adequate resources; and (iv) underestimation of complexity and/or costs, or other design weaknesses. A large number of Bank projects with land titling components involved redistribution of existing land rights. In most cases this proved to be a formidable barrier to progress in project implementation, particularly in economies where agrarian interests were strong. 3.4 In a majority of projects, existing infrastructure to undertake land titling activities was weak. Most countries lacked adequate surveying capabilities (both skills and facilities), and were typically unable to overcome these shortcomings in an effective and timely manner. The projects in Brazil and Thailand point to the need to plan carefully for the introduction and assimilation of new mapping and survey technologies. This challenge was met very successfully in the case of Thailand, where training and technical assistance were incorporated and where the geographical scale matched the numbers of trained staff. In the case of Brazil, the approach to modernize the cadastral database was not adequately discussed with, or understood by, the client prior to implementation. 3.5 The lack of adequate incentives, bonuses, or career development prospects for staff is cited as a serious weakness. In the case of Thailand, the implementing agency was unable to retain many of the trained staff who left for positions elsewhere in the government or joined the private sector. In a number of countries, management links between agencies at central government level and regional and district offices were too weak to coordinate implementation. In extreme cases, district registration offices were not even established during the life of the project. Lack of training at regional and district levels also contributed to poor performance. 3.6 The Brazil project suffered from an ineffective coordination unit due to: (i) repeated changes in structure and staffing; (ii) insufficient authority to supervise implementation; (iii) lack of

LESSONS 3.7 Land titling and registration projects must incorporate the following key elements: (i) a single agency must have overall responsibility for implementation with clear and well-functioning management links at all levels; (ii) implementation units must be adequately staffed, funded and trained; (iii) implementation units must be empowered by law to coordinate project activities; (iv) projects should be designed on the basis of existing human skills and institutional arrangements so as to be able to assimilate technological advances; and, (v) capabilities need to be further enhanced through institutional development including training and technical assistance. 3.8 Projects which have focused on the registration of existing rights have proved much more successful than those addressing a reallocation of rights. More crucially, a project must be consistent with a government's own plans to address land use questions. This was considered to be a critical factor in the success of the Thailand project. 3.9 Land titling and registration costs can greatly exceed expectations where due attention is not paid to procedures for adjudication, demarcation, survey and dispute settlement. Maximum use of photogrammetric methods, as opposed to field work for existing parcels, has also proved to be economically expedient. It is important that relevant government policies in these areas be reviewed and addressed during project preparation. 3.10 Due to the specialized nature of equipment for such projects, careful attention must be given to preparation of bid documents and bid evaluation procedures. Projects should be designed to reflect realistic possibilities for coordinating aerial photography, map production, adjudication, registration and the issue of title certificates. The scale of the project should be commensurate with the ability of the borrower to staff district and provincial offices with trained personnel, carry out registration activity and provide adequate resources. Finally, staff involved in project supervision and implementation must have appropriate incentives, including salary bonuses, and career advancement opportunities. C. LESSONS IN THE FSU 3.11 The Bank has undertaken similar projects in a number of countries in the former Soviet Union (FSU). The LARIS project for Russia is the first Bank project which deals with land registration in the FSU. This project was prepared during 1993/1994 and is now in implementation. Preparation is underway for a land registration project in Ukraine. Experience from these projects shows that the lack of a firm legal basis, the existence of strong inter-agency rivalries for control of registration, and the lack of policy consensus on the goal of markets in land and real estate complicate project development. 3.12 There are many parallels among Russia, Ukraine, and Kazakstan in terms of the starting point of a Soviet land tenure framework, the early developments in land law before the break up of the USSR and the origins and nature of the institutions now involved in land administration and management. Kazakstan shares with Russia its economic inheritance and the present state of its economy, particularly in the agricultural sector, is equally problematic.

There are several well-know principles of information management which will be applied to the Kazakstan registration system. 4.30 Unique Identification. Each piece of information should be uniquely identified by a number, or key, which is guaranteed not to be duplicated. This applies equally to the subjects, objects, and rights included in the system. Each uniquely identifiable piece of information regarding rights and changes in rights should be assigned a code, or reference number. For example, the change of right (or encumbrance) which we call release of mortgage can be replaced by a code assigned by the Government. The pilot project will undertake to establish this system of unique identification codes. 4.31 Non-duplicadon of Information. When information is used by organizations or agencies that are dispersed geographically, it is important that these agencies are assured of the accuracy and timeliness of the information. In order to ensure the validity of information, the following principles will be followed: (i) Only one valid ( legal ) copy of the subject information should exist; (ii) The person or organization responsible for the maintenance of the information should be clearly identified; and (iii) Physical copies of information should be kept to an absolute minimum. These copies should be clearly identified as copies, or technology and procedures can be employed to ensure that copies are valid. 4.32 Adherence to these principles will require reliable arrangements for information sharing among participating agencies. 4.33 Information Protection. For rayons implementing the paper-based system, the pilot project will follow practices used in many Western countries of locking registration books and controlled access to those books by the public. KEY ASSUMPTiONS AND RISKS 7.1 A major reason for choosing a pilot project to address the task of establishing a real estate registration system in Kazakstan was precisely that the risks associated with this undertaking were significant. The following assumptions and risks are associated with the project components. 7.2 For the project to be successful, counterpart funds sufficient to staff and house the new registration offices will be essential. The Government is required by the Registration Law to establish these offices. The transfer of the former BTI offices to the Ministry of Justice avoids unnecessary duplication of work, but still represents a net burden on the national budget. By limiting the scope of the pilot project, the immediate financial burden on the Government is reduced. Because the project foresees cost recovery mechanisms through a system of fees for service, roll out of a successful pilot will require less of a net drain on the budget. This will be monitored closely during implementation. Arrangements for cost-sharing among the national, oblast and rayon budgets will also be closely monitored during implementation. 7.3 The Ministry of Justice at present lacks the capacity to implement the project. The Bank has proposed programs of training and technical assistance which are well designed to meet the institution building needs of the Ministry of Justice. Here, too, the immediate burden on the Ministry of Justice is reduced as a result of the pilot scale of the project. The training programs, once established, will provide the necessary skills to implement the pilot as well as to prepare for expansion of the system beyond the project rayons. The civil service pay scale may represent an obstacle in the retention of staff receiving training in automated technology and for the location of appropriate individuals as rayon chief registrars. 7.4 Appropriate cooperation among relevant agencies is required for the project to be fully successful. A breakdown in inter-agency cooperation would seriously undercut prospects for implementation of the new registration system. The agencies assisting the Ministry of Justice in establishing the registration system have mandates that go well beyond the scope of registration. The Land Committee has significant land administration and land monitoring functions under the recently adopted Land Code. The city and rayon architects offices are reasserting their roles as building inspection offices. In addition, the information needed for the registration system represents a small piece of the data bases of these organizations and therefore, not a threat to their future areas of work. The pilot project approach will allow for flexibility in design and the precise nature of inter-agency cooperation. 7.5 Experience from similar projects (both Bank and non-Bank financed) shows that provision of user-interface software frequently runs into delays and holds up planned implementation of automated information systems. The Bank has emphasized this potential danger beginning with the last preparation mission and has encouraged the Government to locate necessary consultants to complete this work. Use of the PPF to get necessary consultants on board well ahead of loan effectiveness will reduce the risk of delays in developing the user-interface software. Again, because of the pilot nature of the project the software will undergo extensive testing during project implementation, which allows time for elaboration of a fully tested version for wider implementation.
 - 31 - 7.6 Procurement of most automated technology under this project will be in accordance with ICB procedures. This will entail a good deal of lead time to complete. As experience from the Region shows, lack of familiarity with ICB can significantly delay project implementation. The Bank has located trust funds for preparation of bidding documents and has conducted a one-week review in Washington with consultants financed by these trust funds of the latest World Bank standard documents for procurement of goods and procurement of computer equipment. The Bank has also provided assistance in finalizing the technical specifications for the bidding documents. 7.7 Because the ultimate goal of the pilot is to provide a reliable basis for a national system, the following further assumptions and risks should be considered. It is assumed that the population will choose to use the system. While the Law does not make registration of property rights mandatory, it does recognize the superiority of registered to unregistered rights. Fragmented registration of rights in real estate has already taken place in the form of issuing State Acts for land and Privatization Acts for other real estate, indicating the population's interest in such protection. The incentive to register property rights will be strong not only for new owners, but for those holding servitudes or encumbrances on a property, for example, a bank holding a mortgage or an individual holding a right-of-way across a neighbor's parcel. Development of a registration system will facilitate the collection of tax revenue, and in that way provide disincentives to participate. While there was interest expressed by some in building a true fiscal cadastre into the project, the project design has remained squarely focused on the legal cadastre, thereby emphasizing the property rights aspects of the system. 7.8 For the system to be financially sustainable, the level of market activity must be sufficient to generate necessary revenues. Project oblasts have been selected in large part based on anticipated market activity in the immediate term. Sales of real estate (both ownership and use rights) is already well developed. The existing legislative framework is considered sufficient for market activity in real estate to develop further. B. BENEFITS 7.11 A register of titles represents an important part of the public infrastructure of a market- based economy. Clarification and security of rights in real property are an essential step in the transition from the pre-reform economy of Kazakstan. Reliable registration is the means by which capital investment in real estate in increasingly complex economies is secured and traded.
 - 32 - 7.12 The economic benefits to the individual or corporate owner of real estate rights are numerous. First, security of tenure is backed by the State, putting the ownership of the rights beyond dispute and providing the basis on which owners of rights can expend effort and capital with the confident expectation of earning a return. The register provides the basis on which mortgagees can secure collateral for the loans they make. At present, mortgaging of real property is significantly hindered by the lack of reliable documentation of rights. The ability to transact real estate rights enables successful businesses to grow and allows the rights of businesses which fail to be reallocated through the market, rather than left idle or underutilized. By facilitating sales and leases, the registration system improves the functioning of these markets, and in turn, the valuation of real property. The function of a register to assist in the continuing process of farm restructuring is especially significant in this respect. The project will reduce the number of boundary disputes by utilizing a method of parcel adjudication which incorporates input and agreement from neighbors on boundary location at the time of registration. 7.13 The registration system provides further benefits to the Government by establishing the essential legal layer in a cadastral information system. A reliable legal cadastre will provide the Government with an improved information basis for assessing the value of real property and in the functioning of the tax administration. The legal cadastre can be supplemented subsequently with relevant fiscal information to further improve the process of property assessment and real estate tax collection. The establishment of the legal cadastre will assist the Government in carrying out its administrative functions with respect to land and real estate. In the process of registering rights, land and real estate remaining in public ownership will likewise be recorded in the register. Unauthorized dealings in such property can be prevented and thus the register will help to maintain the integrity of public lands and designated sites of special environmental or other importance. 7.14 The project will allow the Government to test alternative technologies in implementing a registration system in the project oblasts prior to making decisions about expansion of the system nationwide. Phased implementation of the registration system, utilizing a pilot project first, also allows time for necessary institution building and the testing of office procedures, formats, and inter-agency working relations on a modest scale, prior to implementation on a broad scale. D. BENEFICIARIES 7.15 The primary beneficiaries of the project will be holders of rights in land and other real estate. In rural and urban sectors, the project will help to secure these rights and their value. In agriculture the register will help to provide entry and exit mechanisms for farmers. In urban areas, the market backed by the register will help mobility of people and businesses. The register will increase the security of transactions and reduce the cost. In the long term the nation will benefit from improved agricultural production and revenues. 7.16 The Government will benefit from the project in terms of building essential institutional capacity within the involved agencies; the Ministry of Justice, the State Land Committee, and the Ministry of Construction.

doc.abstracts: The Real Estate Registration Pilot Project s objective will be to support Kasakstan's effort to establish a national registration system of real estate rights and transactions, as mandated by the legally enforceable Presidential Decree. This decree increases security for rights to land and real estate, facilitates transactions in land and real estate, and promotes credit systems development. The project will also test the use of digital mapping for registration system support, and for current and long-term requirements for map production and revision. The project comprises three components: (1) institution building; (2) establishment of the registration system; and (3) map production. The first component consists of developing a Project Implementation Unit, providing technical assistance in elaborating and testing aspects of the registration system, and implementing training programs. The second component establishes the registration offices of the Ministry of Justice, defines linkages between those offices and the offices of the State Land Committee and the Ministry of Construction, locates premises and hires staff, sets up procedures to enter and maintain information in the registry, designs office procedures and standard forms, and installs and tests database management practices. The third component tests and elaborates map digitization on a pilot basis, trains staff, examines the economic costs and benefits of shifting from paper-based maps to electronic maps, and establishes a digitization center that will add parcel boundary information to these base maps.
